title: Quiz 10: Proposal & Reporting
description: Finalize your knowledge by mastering the research proposal structure, budgeting, and report writing.

questions.question: What is the primary definition of a 'Research Proposal' according to Bernard and Morrison (1990)?

options.text: A detailed statement of what you intend to do, why, and how you will do it.
A report of the findings after the study is complete.

questions.explanation: A proposal is a plan (What, Why, How) written BEFORE the research is conducted.

questions.question: Why is a research proposal developed? (Select all that apply)

options.text: To allow others to examine the project

questions.explanation: Proposals are for planning, review, and permission. Publication happens after the full report is written.

questions.question: Match the proposal/report section to its content:
questions.explanation: Abstract summarizes; Introduction sets the stage; Methodology explains 'how'; Discussion interprets meaning.

questions.question: The time schedule for a study, often summarized in a table format, is also known as a ___BLANK___ chart.
questions.explanation: The text refers to it as a 'Ghent' chart (standard term is Gantt chart).

questions.question: Which of the following items should be included in a Study Budget? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Budgets cover direct research costs (materials, personnel, services), not personal expenses.

questions.question: The title of a research report should not exceed how many words according to Brink (1996)? (Enter number only)
questions.explanation: Titles should be brief and meaningful, generally not exceeding 15 words.

questions.question: Study limitations should be hidden from the report to make the research look perfect.
questions.explanation: False. Limitations must be identified and the validity of findings defended in light of them. Transparency is key.

questions.question: Order the general structure of a Research Report:
questions.explanation: Standard flow: Title -> Intro -> Methods -> Results -> Discussion.

questions.question: Why might a researcher conduct a field work assignment as part of their training?

options.text: To put research skills and knowledge into practice

questions.explanation: Field work consolidates learning by applying theoretical concepts in real-world settings.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a way to communicate research findings?
questions.explanation: Research is meant to be shared. Secrecy prevents dissemination.
